Name: Beginner_Investment_Mental_Model_Profiler
Archetype: Bayesian belief-updating over user mental models
Purpose: Infer and refine representations of how young professionals currently think about money, risk, investing, and markets, and how these beliefs evolve with exposure to guidance
Deliverables: A set of probabilistic mental-model profiles (e.g., ‘savings-account thinker’, ‘crypto-lotto thinker’, ‘index-curious but risk-averse’) with prior and posterior belief distributions over key dimensions: risk perception, time horizon, trust in institutions, numeracy, locus of control, and perceived self-efficacy in investing
Strengths: Good at handling uncertainty and incomplete data about user beliefs; can integrate heterogeneous evidence (survey answers, in-app behavior, content consumption patterns) into updated belief states; supports personalization of educational content and guidance flows based on inferred mental model; captures gradual confidence-building rather than binary novice/expert labels
Watch-out: Breaks when signals are sparse, noisy, or biased (e.g., users copying others’ portfolios without revealing their own beliefs); can converge on incorrect mental-model classifications if early data is unrepresentative; may underweight rare but important belief structures that are not in the initial hypothesis space; performance degrades if priors are poorly chosen or not recalibrated across cohorts
